semantic:
Sigma (sigma) is the electrical conductivity measured in siemens per meter(S·m<sup>−1</sup>)

<math>G =\frac 1 R =\sigma \cdot \frac{A}{l}</math>

In This formula <math> \sigma, {A},{l},</math> are constant,therefore <math>G</math> already is constant. 

{{clear}}

Basic kinematics: thumb|'''Newton's Cradle'''. When you let go of the near ball, it transfers its momentum to the far ball, which (assuming no friction or heat losses) should swing up to the same height at which you lifted the first ball. Carnot engine: right|thumb|350px|How to calculate the slope of the adiabatic compression curve.

right|thumb|500px|The blue line shows the relationship between P and V at the high temperature T<sub>HOT</sub>=600.  The green line shows the relationship at T<sub>COLD</sub>=200.  The red line shows the adiabatic compression trajectory upward and to the left.  The graphs are calibrated as though '''NR'''=.05 and '''C'''=1.5, as it is for monoatomic gases.

right|thumb|500px|Closeup view showing the complete Carnot cycle.  The adiabatic compression phase goes from '''W''' to '''X''' along the red line.  The isothermal expansion phase goes from '''X''' to '''Y''' along the blue line.  The adiabatic expansion phase goes from '''Y''' to '''Z''' along the magenta line.  The isothermal compression phase goes from '''Z''' back to '''W''' along the green line.
right|thumb|333px|Illustrate Carnot's theorem by showing a more efficient heat engine violating the second law of thermodynamics.

Cross product: thumb|right|The cross-product is perpendicular to the vectors a and b, and points in the direction of the thumb of the right hand when the fingers curl in the direction to move a to b.  If the order of the vectors were reversed, the fingers would curl in the opposite direction, so the cross product would point in the opposite direction.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 1.  The "star" operation is the projection of a vector onto the plane <math>P\,</math>.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 2.  <math>\vec{A}</math> and <math>\vec{A}^*</math> give the same cross product.
left|thumb|250px|Figure 3.  Two vectors, with their "star" projection vectors.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 4.  Addition of the two vectors.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 5, showing the parallelogram rule when viewed directly down on the plane.  The green dot symbolizes vector C pointing directly toward the viewer.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 6, showing various vectors and their cross products with C.  All of these vectors lie in the plane perpendicular to C.
right|thumb|250px|Figure 7.  Cartesian basis vectors.  The system is right handed.
